newsitem.title: FRANCE: Arthuis says Daewoo not ruled out for Thomson.
newsitem.headline: Arthuis says Daewoo not ruled out for Thomson.

text.p: French Finance Minister Jean Arthuis told journalists the government's decision to suspend the sale of Thomson SA to Lagardere Groupe did not mean that Daewoo Electronics was out of the race.

Earlier on Wednesday the government called off the controversial sale after the independent Privatisation Commission objected to terms of Lagardere's intended sale of consumer electronics unit Thomson Multimedia to South Korea's Daewoo.
"The Privatisation Commission has told us that it could not give a positive advice about the preferred sale (to Lagardere and Daewoo) and the government has drawn the conclusions," Arthuis said.

"There is no question of going back on the intention to privatise Thomson," he added, noting that the commission had not objected to the state's planned capital injection of some 11 billion francs prior to a sale.

"The Privatisation Commission considered that there would have been a transfer of technology in the field od digital (televisions and decoders) and flat screens and that this technology was the result of research financed with the help of public funds," he said.
"Also, the legal terms of the sale were not sufficient to give guarantees that Daewoo Electronics would for ever be active in France.

"It is not the quality of any of the companies concerned, not Lagardere nor Daewoo Electronics, that is being questioned. What is being questioned is the terms of the transfer between Thomson and Daewoo," Arthuis said.

"We are going to restart this privatisation procedure. Certainly, we have lost some weeks but everybody is convinced that the future of the group and the situation of staff at Thomson-CSF and Thomson Multimedia depend on the privatisation."
